articles.headline: F.D.A. Offers Broad New Rules to Fight Food Contamination
articles.snippet: Under a proposal, the Food and Drug Administration would shift from taking action after contamination occurred to requiring measures to prevent it in the first place.
articles.abstract: Under a proposal, the Food and Drug Administration would shift from taking action after contamination occurred to requiring measures to prevent it in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday proposed two sweeping rules aimed at preventing the contamination of produce and processed foods, which has sickened tens of thousands of Americans annually in recent years.

articles.headline: The Line Between ‘Aggressive’ and ‘Evil’
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission’s antitrust ruling on Google was a victory for the search giant, but it’s unclear if consumers won, too.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission’s antitrust ruling on Google was a victory for the search giant, but it’s unclear if consumers won, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Don’t Be Evil,” the founders of Google, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, proclaimed in their 2004 “Owner’s Manual” for prospective investors in the company. Despite widespread cynicism, criticism and even mockery, the company has never backed down on this core premise, reiterating in its most recent list of the “things we know to be true” that “you can make money without doing evil.”

articles.headline: An Invitation for High School Seniors to Write About Finances
articles.snippet: This column invites high school seniors to submit essays on working, class and affluence, topics that have become common on college applications.
articles.abstract: This column invites high school seniors to submit essays on working, class and affluence, topics that have become common on college applications.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the University of Michigan, one application essay talked about how local education cutbacks forced high school students to pay money to play team sports. As a result, the writer could no longer afford to play.

articles.headline: Rally Signals Fatah’s Rift With Hamas May Ease
articles.snippet: A show of unity between rival Palestinian factions posed a diplomatic quandary for the United States, which considers Hamas a terrorist organization.
articles.abstract: A show of unity between rival Palestinian factions posed a diplomatic quandary for the United States, which considers Hamas a terrorist organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Turning the streets of Gaza City into a swarm of sunshine-yellow flags, hundreds of thousands of Palestinians celebrated the anniversary of the Fatah faction on Friday in the heartland of its militant Islamist rival, Hamas, the latest in a series of signals heralding possible reconciliation between the parties after their bitter five-year rift.

articles.headline: Exports of American Natural Gas May Fall Short of High Hopes
articles.snippet: Global demand for natural gas — which would be shipped from the United States in a condensed form — could taper off by the time new and costly export terminals are ready.
articles.abstract: Global demand for natural gas — which would be shipped from the United States in a condensed form — could taper off by the time new and costly export terminals are ready.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Only five years ago, several giant natural gas import terminals were built to satisfy the energy needs of a country hungry for fuels. But the billion-dollar terminals were obsolete even before the concrete was dry as an unexpected drilling boom in new shale fields from Pennsylvania to Texas produced a glut of cheap domestic natural gas.

articles.headline: U.S. Settles Accusations That Doctors Overtreated
articles.snippet: A hospital in Ohio agreed to pay $3.9 million over allegations that doctors billed Medicare for unneeded heart procedures.
articles.abstract: A hospital in Ohio agreed to pay $3.9 million over allegations that doctors billed Medicare for unneeded heart procedures.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of doctors who performed unusually high rates of heart procedures on patients at a community hospital in Ohio settled with the Justice Department over accusations that some of the procedures were medically unnecessary, federal regulators announced on Friday.

articles.headline: On Google, F.T.C. Set Rules of War Over Patents
articles.snippet: The end of smartphone patent lawsuits is by no means near, but legal experts say an F.T.C. settlement signals progress in clarifying the rules in high-tech patent battles, and thus could ease them.
articles.abstract: The end of smartphone patent lawsuits is by no means near, but legal experts say an F.T.C. settlement signals progress in clarifying the rules in high-tech patent battles, and thus could ease them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission’s antitrust investigation of Google focused mainly on the company’s lucrative search business, while its inquiry into the tech giant’s handling of patents seemed an afterthought.

articles.headline: Tax Code May Be the Most Progressive Since 1979
articles.snippet: The deal struck by Congress raised taxes on a handful of the highest-earning Americans, with about 99.3 percent of households experiencing no change in their income taxes.
articles.abstract: The deal struck by Congress raised taxes on a handful of the highest-earning Americans, with about 99.3 percent of households experiencing no change in their income taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With 2013 bringing tax increases on the incomes of a small sliver of the richest Americans, the country’s top earners now face a heavier tax burden than at any time since Jimmy Carter was president.

articles.headline: After Years in Solitary, an Austere Life as Uruguay’s President
articles.snippet: José Mujica, a former guerrilla who took office in 2010, shuns opulence, donates most of his salary and lives modestly, as he says a leader of a proper democracy should.
articles.abstract: José Mujica, a former guerrilla who took office in 2010, shuns opulence, donates most of his salary and lives modestly, as he says a leader of a proper democracy should.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — Some world leaders live in palaces. Some enjoy perks like having a discreet butler, a fleet of yachts or a wine cellar with vintage Champagnes. Then there is José Mujica, the former guerrilla who is Uruguay’s president. He lives in a run-down house on Montevideo’s outskirts with no servants at all. His security detail: two plainclothes officers parked on a dirt road.

articles.headline: Ex-Officer Is First From C.I.A. to Face Prison for a Leak
articles.snippet: John C. Kiriakou says he did not intend to harm national security and doesn’t think he did. But he is set to be sentenced to 30 months for disclosing classified information to a reporter.
articles.abstract: John C. Kiriakou says he did not intend to harm national security and doesn’t think he did. But he is set to be sentenced to 30 months for disclosing classified information to a reporter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Looking back, John C. Kiriakou admits he should have known better. But when the F.B.I. called him a year ago and invited him to stop by and “help us with a case,” he did not hesitate.

articles.headline: Surprise, Surprise: The Banks Win
articles.snippet: For borrowers, a proposed settlement with big banks over foreclosure practices is likely to mean tiny slices of a shrunken pie.
articles.abstract: For borrowers, a proposed settlement with big banks over foreclosure practices is likely to mean tiny slices of a shrunken pie.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you were hoping that things might be different in 2013 — you know, that bankers would be held responsible for bad behavior or that the government might actually assist troubled homeowners — you can forget it. A settlement reportedly in the works with big banks will soon end a review into foreclosure abuses, and it means more of the same: no accountability for financial institutions and little help for borrowers.

articles.headline: The Crowdfunding Crowd Is Anxious
articles.snippet: For new businesses, the regulatory path to crowdfunding — Internet-based financing that involves ordinary investors — is still far from clear.
articles.abstract: For new businesses, the regulatory path to crowdfunding — Internet-based financing that involves ordinary investors — is still far from clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: RYAN CALDBECK was stumped. A director at a private equity firm, he was taking part in a panel discussion at a consumer goods conference last summer in New York when an entrepreneur raised his hand with a question: Where could a young company with just a few million dollars in sales go for money to grow?

articles.headline: Health Insurers Raise Some Rates by Double Digits
articles.snippet: Even though regulators are required by the new health care law to review requests for a large rate increases, many states have not given the overseers any authority to deny or roll back rates that are deemed excessive.
articles.abstract: Even though regulators are required by the new health care law to review requests for a large rate increases, many states have not given the overseers any authority to deny or roll back rates that are deemed excessive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Health insurance companies across the country are seeking and winning double-digit increases in premiums for some customers, even though one of the biggest objectives of the Obama administration’s health care law was to stem the rapid rise in insurance costs for consumers.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Begins Soul-Searching After Tax Vote
articles.snippet: From Mitt Romney’s loss through the recent tax fight, Republicans have seen the foundations of their strategy called into question, stirring a debate about how to reshape the party.
articles.abstract: From Mitt Romney’s loss through the recent tax fight, Republicans have seen the foundations of their strategy called into question, stirring a debate about how to reshape the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Republican leaders in Congress agreed to raise taxes on the wealthy last week, it left the increasingly fractured and feuding party unified on perhaps only one point: that it is at a major crossroads.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: As Putin’s Grip Gets Tighter, a Time of Protest Fades in Russia
articles.snippet: The excitement around last year’s street activism against Vladimir V. Putin, now president again, is gone. But steps by the government are still setting off waves of indignation.
articles.abstract: The excitement around last year’s street activism against Vladimir V. Putin, now president again, is gone. But steps by the government are still setting off waves of indignation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As the final days of 2012 slipped away, no one at Denis Terekhov’s company was talking about the next antigovernment protest.

articles.headline: Defiant Speech by Assad Is New Block to Peace in Syria
articles.snippet: President Bashar al-Assad ruled out talks with the armed opposition and ignored its demand that he step down, instead using a nearly hourlong speech to justify his crackdown.
articles.abstract: President Bashar al-Assad ruled out talks with the armed opposition and ignored its demand that he step down, instead using a nearly hourlong speech to justify his crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Sounding defiant, confident and, to critics, out of touch with his people’s grievances, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Sunday used his first public address in six months to justify his harsh crackdown, rally his supporters to fight against his opponents and inform on them — and leave in tatters recent efforts toward a political resolution to the country’s bloody civil war.

articles.headline: Obama’s Pick for Defense Is an Ally, and a Lightning Rod
articles.snippet: The White House is betting that opposition to Chuck Hagel, a maverick Republican former senator nominated for defense secretary, won’t stop his confirmation in the Senate.
articles.abstract: The White House is betting that opposition to Chuck Hagel, a maverick Republican former senator nominated for defense secretary, won’t stop his confirmation in the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama nominates Chuck Hagel, the maverick Republican and former senator from Nebraska, to be his next secretary of defense, he will be turning to a trusted ally whose willingness to defy party loyalty and conventional wisdom won his admiration both in the Senate and on a 2008 tour of war zones in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Banks Win an Easing of Rules on Assets
articles.snippet: A group of top regulators gave banks around the world more time to meet rules aimed at preventing financial crises, saying they wanted to avoid damaging the economic recovery.
articles.abstract: A group of top regulators gave banks around the world more time to meet rules aimed at preventing financial crises, saying they wanted to avoid damaging the economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of top regulators and central bankers on Sunday gave banks around the world more time to meet new rules aimed at preventing financial crises, saying they wanted to avoid the possibility of damaging the economic recovery.

articles.headline: Cable Companies Squeeze More Obscure Channels
articles.snippet: Distributors are reviewing low-rated channels, and those without a major media company to back them are in danger of being dropped.
articles.abstract: Distributors are reviewing low-rated channels, and those without a major media company to back them are in danger of being dropped.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of cable channels in the United States: those operated by major media companies that have dozens of other channels, and those that are on their own.

articles.headline: Old Media’s Stalwarts Persevered in 2012
articles.snippet: For the time being, the sky over traditional media is blue and it’s raining green.
articles.abstract: For the time being, the sky over traditional media is blue and it’s raining green.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that traditional media companies are dead in the water, overwhelmed by ad skipping, cord cutting and audience flight. We know that because Chicken Littles (like me) have been saying it for years.

articles.headline: As Sales Slip, TV Makers Strain for the Next Sensation
articles.snippet: Television makers are trying to attract attention by supersizing screens and quadrupling the level of detail in images, and they are adding apps and other interactive elements.
articles.abstract: Television makers are trying to attract attention by supersizing screens and quadrupling the level of detail in images, and they are adding apps and other interactive elements.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Your smartphone is the screen in your pocket. Your computer is the screen on your desk. Your tablet is a screen for the couch.

articles.headline: Madoff Aside, Financial Fraud Defies Policing
articles.snippet: For more than two years, Philip Horn, a financial adviser at Wells Fargo, systematically executed and canceled trades in clients’ portfolios, pocketing the profits, according to court documents.
articles.abstract: For more than two years, Philip Horn, a financial adviser at Wells Fargo, systematically executed and canceled trades in clients’ portfolios, pocketing the profits, according to court documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — To Philip Horn, the Braemar Country Club was not just a golf course, it was an extension of his office. Most weeks, Mr. Horn, a financial adviser at Wells Fargo, chatted up potential clients between holes at the upscale club set against the backdrop of the Santa Monica Mountains.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Critics of Google Antitrust Ruling Fault the Focus
articles.snippet: Some critics of the inquiry say the Federal Trade Commission should have considered harm to Google’s advertisers, not just searchers.
articles.abstract: Some critics of the inquiry say the Federal Trade Commission should have considered harm to Google’s advertisers, not just searchers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the more surprising conclusions drawn by the Federal Trade Commission when it dropped its nearly two-year antitrust investigation into Google last week was that Google, far from harming consumers, had actually helped them.

articles.headline: Major Companies Push the Limits of a Tax Break
articles.snippet: The practice of exchanging one asset for another without incurring taxes has spread to major corporations from the family farmers the tax break was intended to help.
articles.abstract: The practice of exchanging one asset for another without incurring taxes has spread to major corporations from the family farmers the tax break was intended to help.
articles.lead_paragraph: It began more than 90 years ago as a small tax break intended to help family farmers who wanted to swap horses and land. Farmers who sold property, livestock or equipment were allowed to avoid paying capital gains taxes, as long as they used the proceeds to replace or upgrade their assets.

articles.headline: At Disney Parks, a Bracelet Meant to Build Loyalty (and Sales)
articles.snippet: Disney’s coming electronic bracelets will allow its theme park visitors to pay for things as well as guide them to attractions, but the company will gain access to valuable information on its customers.
articles.abstract: Disney’s coming electronic bracelets will allow its theme park visitors to pay for things as well as guide them to attractions, but the company will gain access to valuable information on its customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Imagine Walt Disney World with no entry turnstiles. Cash? Passé: Visitors would wear rubber bracelets encoded with credit card information, snapping up corn dogs and Mickey Mouse ears with a tap of the wrist. Smartphone alerts would signal when it is time to ride Space Mountain without standing in line.

articles.headline: Choice to Lead C.I.A. Faces a Changed Agency
articles.snippet: John O. Brennan may have to decide whether the C.I.A. should remain at the center of secret American paramilitary operations or rebuild its traditional espionage capabilities.
articles.abstract: John O. Brennan may have to decide whether the C.I.A. should remain at the center of secret American paramilitary operations or rebuild its traditional espionage capabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nomination on Monday of John O. Brennan as director of the Central Intelligence Agency puts one of his closest and most powerful aides in charge of an agency that has been transformed by more than a decade of secret wars.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: In Deal, Bank of America Extends Retreat From Mortgages
articles.snippet: The problems at Bank of America have cut down its mortgage ambitions; it accounts for 4 percent of the nation’s mortgage market, a slide from just over 20 percent in 2009, ceding market dominance to Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Chase.
articles.abstract: The problems at Bank of America have cut down its mortgage ambitions; it accounts for 4 percent of the nation’s mortgage market, a slide from just over 20 percent in 2009, ceding market dominance to Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Chase.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:00 p.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Protest Grows Over Censoring of China Paper
articles.snippet: A battle over media censorship intensified Monday with an outpouring of support for journalists at a newspaper who are protesting what they called overbearing censorship by Chinese officials.
articles.abstract: A battle over media censorship intensified Monday with an outpouring of support for journalists at a newspaper who are protesting what they called overbearing censorship by Chinese officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Hundreds of people gathered outside the headquarters of a newspaper company in southern China on Monday, intensifying a battle over media censorship that poses a test of the willingness of China’s new leadership to tolerate calls for change.
